Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the

 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (989) 758-2717.

ALLEGATION: Youth A was restrained outside of the restraint
procedures. Youth A did not have any marks or bruises.
INVESTIGATION:
Youth A has been discharged from the facility.
I spoke to Administrator 1 on 2/16/22. Administrator 1 reported that Staff 1 completed a
restraint that was outside of the MACH restraint module. Administrator 1 reported Staff
1 did a “chicken hold”, where he held Youth A’s arms from behind her. Administrator 1
reported there is not a MACH manual, procedural book, or documents in their
possession that show or describe the MACH restraint module.
I reviewed the video footage and Staff 1 did hold Youth A’s arms from behind her. Staff
2 was at the incident but did not engage in the restraint.
I interviewed Staff 1 on 3/22/22. Staff 1 reported Youth A was brought into the facility by
her grandmother. Youth A entered a non-secure area and was attempting to leave the
facility. Once she entered the secure area, Youth A began to verbally escalate and
attempted to run out the door. Staff1 reported at that time, he grabbed her arms and
held her. Staff 1 reported he was trying to do a MACH 3-Team Control hold but couldn’t
do it because there needs to be two staff members completing this technique. Staff 2
was present but was not engaged in the physical restraint. Staff 1 reported his
technique was not consistent with MACH training.
I interviewed Staff 2 on 3/22/22. Staff 2 reported Youth A was screaming, cussing, and
starting to get aggressive. Staff 2 reported Youth A did make threats. Staff 2 reported
Staff 1 grabbed her arms and she verbally deescalated her. Staff 2 reported that most
restraints are initiated with one staff until the other staff can get to the area. Staff 2
reported she did not step in because she was able to verbally deescalate Youth A while
Staff 1 held Youth A. Staff 2 reported that Staff 1 was not overtly aggressive, and she
felt that Staff 1 made a good decision to hold her while she deescalated Youth A.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 on 3/24/22. Supervisor 1 is the MACH trainer. Supervisor 1
reported he does not have a MACH training manual, procedural book, or documents in
his possession that show or describe the MACH restraint module. Supervisor 1 reported
that it is easier to show the MACH restraint module than to verbally describe it. I
attempted to “google” MACH module and did not find this module. Supervisor 1
reported that the manual is not online and that the only MACH training that I would see
3

(online) is the military training. Supervisor 1 reported that a restraint is conducted when
a youth is a threat to others or themselves, if they corner staff, advance towards staff or
throwing objects that could potentially hurt others. Supervisor 1 reported he attends
training for MACH and then trains others at the facility but stated there are no manuals
or procedures written down for the actual restraint techniques. Supervisor 1 reported
that there are no MACH techniques that would have you hold a child from behind them.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and
procedures regarding restraint. These policies and
procedures shall be available to all residents, their families,
and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: Based upon interview with Supervisor 1, the hold that Staff 1
completed was not part of MACH training. Staff 1 reported that
he did not follow MACH protocol as well.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE

and

procedures shall be available to all residents, their families,
and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: Both Administrator 1 and Supervisor 1 reported there are no
written procedures for the MACH training module.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
A. It is recommended that the license remain unchanged.
